missed.title: Path Traversal Vulnerability
missed.reason: The penetration test did not discover or report any path traversal vulnerabilities. No attempts to access files outside the intended directory using '../' or similar patterns were documented in the actual findings. The test focused on HTTP headers and form validation rather than directory traversal attack vectors.

missed.title: Local File Inclusion (LFI)
missed.reason: The penetration test did not discover or report any local file inclusion vulnerabilities. No attempts to manipulate file inclusion parameters were documented. The application serves static files via SimpleHTTP, but the test did not identify or report LFI as a vulnerability, focusing instead on other security configuration issues.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - Verbose Server Error Messages Revealing Version Information
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. The application discloses server version (SimpleHTTP/0.6 Python/3.13.3) in HTTP 501 error responses for unsupported methods. This is a valid information disclosure vulnerability that enables reconnaissance attacks.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers - Critical Protection Headers Not Implemented
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. Multiple critical HTTP security headers are missing (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, CSP, HSTS, X-XSS-Protection, Referrer-Policy, Permissions-Policy). This is a valid configuration vulnerability that exposes the application to multiple attack vectors.

extra.title: Missing Critical HTTP Security Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding (duplicate/related to Missing Security Headers finding). Provides detailed evidence of missing CSP, X-Frame-Options, HSTS, X-Content-Type-Options, and X-XSS-Protection headers with specific impact assessment for each missing header.

extra.title: Missing Cache Control Headers - Enables Cache Poisoning and Information Disclosure
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. The application lacks Cache-Control, Pragma, and Expires headers on all responses, allowing indefinite caching by browsers and intermediaries. This enables cache poisoning attacks and information disclosure risks.

extra.title: Client-Side Only Validation - Reliance on HTML5 Form Attributes
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. The contact form implements validation only on the client-side using HTML5 attributes. This can be bypassed through browser developer tools, curl, or direct HTTP requests. Demonstrates poor security practice if a backend is added.

extra.title: Missing Subresource Integrity (SRI) on External Scripts - Enables CDN/MitM Attack
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. External libraries (jQuery 3.5.1, Bootstrap 4.5.2, Popper.js) are loaded from CDNs without SRI integrity attributes. This enables attackers to inject malicious code if they compromise the CDN or perform MITM attacks.

extra.title: Insufficient Input Length Validation on Contact Form Fields
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. Form input fields (name, email, message) lack maxlength attributes, allowing unlimited data submission. This could lead to resource exhaustion or DoS attacks if a backend is added that processes these inputs.

extra.title: Information Disclosure Through Server Header
extra.assessment: New discovery - legitimate security finding. The Server header on all HTTP responses discloses detailed version information (SimpleHTTP/0.6 Python/3.13.3). This provides attackers with reconnaissance data for identifying known vulnerabilities.
